body:
I personally think chaining is one of the only desirable things about extends. But it seems like I have a different opinion about extends in general lol.

If A extends B, then by definition, A _is_  sharing the properties of B. So when C extends A, that means that C is also extending B by proxy - because A is already extending B. IMO, exact matching only + chaining + extending mixins = as close to comprehensive and predictable results as possible.

I don't have any objection to it, just wasn't sure about it. I think I would expect it to chain.. my only worry is whether detecting circular loops will be easy or not and whether it will be hard to predict.
Ah, yeah that sounds difficult. Since I'm pretty useless in that regard, I'll have to defer to your larger brain on such matters!
Since each selector is a unique identifier, won't circular references just become a no-op? I agree that `extend` should cascade by default, that's the natural expectation. Stylus already does this.

> agree that extend should cascade by default, that's the natural expectation.

that was my observation as well, and I thought how Stylus implemented this feature made a lot more sense than how SASS did it
@jonschlinkert is right. As with other languages, if B extends A, and then C extends B, it means that C will have some properties of A, it's a normal inheritance chain, with predictable results.

I'm talking about the implementation, not the specification re: circular
references, but I'm sure I can get round it. I will have a go at
implementing tomorrow, it isn't a natural extension to the existing code
but I think it is reasonably easy to do.
why do I have the feeling someone is about to ask for circular reference as a feature of extends? lol jk

@ricardobeat @matthewdl 

It is not that simple. If you work out how to detect this scenario

https://github.com/cloudhead/less.js/blob/master/test/less/errors/extend-circular.less

in a way other than this

https://github.com/cloudhead/less.js/blob/master/lib/less/extend-visitor.js#L121

(note I already check the parent chain here

https://github.com/cloudhead/less.js/blob/master/lib/less/extend-visitor.js#L138

) then I'll bow to your superior abilities but I've given up. Maybe I've been staring at chaining examples for too long. Maybe its just a bug.

Note that we do successfully ignore self referencing as in here

https://github.com/cloudhead/less.js/blob/master/test/less/extend-chaining.less#L42

answer with a pull request please :)

just have chaining inside media queries to do...

@lukeapage if I may add something here, inheritance chaining should rather not be looked with a double if statement+ternary operator. A global class table should be formed in memory with positions for parent child, and then work on this one. :)
@Merg1255 you are welcome to rewrite it

and there are definitely performance improvements that could be made. Plus working out the extends chaining as a tree before adding new extends in order to do proper circular reference checking would make it easier.. but I have limited time to spend on this and less isn't performance critical unless you are using it in a browser in production and we don't recommend doing that no matter what you use in your less.

ok, on a another check, I think maybe we should adopt an easy way of inheritance, ie simple single inheritance, just for the sake of simplicity. :)
There's gonna be an issue if C extends B, and B extends A, but then also A extends AA which extends C. It's just too much of checking for a css file, and I don't think inheritance is the primary concern of web devs.

ok, just being curious, what would indeed be done if we have

``` css
.b:extend(.c) { }
.c:extend(.b) { }
```

Should the compiling stop and emit a JS console message?
btw, a tree structure has unique children with specified levels of inheritance. here, child C is both a parent and child to B, so this might need another approach.
